intro: Dianthus inaequalis, commonly known as the unequal carnation, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is characterized by its showy, pink or white flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and has hairy, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers consist of five petals, with the lower petal being larger and more prominent than the others, giving it its common name. Dianthus inaequalis is often cultivated in gardens for its ornamental value and fragrance.
